defs.docs: Simple getopt alternative.

attributes.value: / Simple getopt alternative.
/ Construct a vector of options, either by using `reqopt`, `optopt`, and
/ `optflag` or by building them from components yourself, and pass them to
/ `getopts`, along with a vector of actual arguments (not including
/ `argv[0]`). You'll either get a failure code back, or a match. You'll have
/ to verify whether the amount of 'free' arguments in the match is what you
/ expect. Use `opt_*` accessors to get argument values out of the matches
/ object.
/ Single-character options are expected to appear on the command line with a
/ single preceding dash; multiple-character options are expected to be
/ proceeded by two dashes. Options that expect an argument accept their
/ argument following either a space or an equals sign. Single-character
/ options don't require the space.
/ # Usage
/ This crate is [on crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/getopts) and can be
/ used by adding `getopts` to the dependencies in your project's `Cargo.toml`.
/ ```toml
/ [dependencies]
/ getopts = "0.2"
/ and this to your crate root:
/ ```rust
/ extern crate getopts;
/ # Example
/ The following example shows simple command line parsing for an application
/ that requires an input file to be specified, accepts an optional output file
/ name following `-o`, and accepts both `-h` and `--help` as optional flags.
/ extern crate getopts;
/ use getopts::Options;
/ use std::env;
/ fn do_work(inp: &str, out: Option<String>) {
/     println!("{}", inp);
/     match out {
/         Some(x) => println!("{}", x),
/         None => println!("No Output"),
/ fn print_usage(program: &str, opts: Options) {
/     let brief = format!("Usage: {} FILE [options]", program);
/     print!("{}", opts.usage(&brief));
/ fn main() {
/     let args: Vec<String> = env::args().collect();
/     let program = args[0].clone();
/     let mut opts = Options::new();
/     opts.optopt("o", "", "set output file name", "NAME");
/     opts.optflag("h", "help", "print this help menu");
/     let matches = match opts.parse(&args[1..]) {
/         Err(f) => { panic!(f.to_string()) }
/     if matches.opt_present("h") {
/         print_usage(&program, opts);
/         return;
/     let output = matches.opt_str("o");
/     let input = if !matches.free.is_empty() {
/         matches.free[0].clone()
/     } else {
/         print_usage(&program, opts);
/         return;
/     do_work(&input, output);
deny(missing_docs)

defs.name: Options
defs.docs: A description of the options that a program can handle.

attributes.value: / A description of the options that a program can handle.

defs.docs: Create a blank set of options.

attributes.value: / Create a blank set of options.

defs.docs: Set the parsing style.

attributes.value: / Set the parsing style.

defs.name: long_only
defs.value: pub fn long_only(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut Options
defs.docs: Set or clear "long options only" mode.

attributes.value: / Set or clear "long options only" mode.
/ In "long options only" mode, short options cannot be clustered
/ together, and long options can be given with either a single
/ "-" or the customary "--".  This mode also changes the meaning
/ of "-a=b"; in the ordinary mode this will parse a short option
/ "-a" with argument "=b"; whereas in long-options-only mode the
/ argument will be simply "b".

defs.name: opt
defs.value: pub fn opt(&mut Self, &str, &str, &str, &str, HasArg, Occur) -> &mut Options
defs.docs: Create a generic option group, stating all parameters explicitly.

attributes.value: / Create a generic option group, stating all parameters explicitly.

defs.name: optflag
defs.docs: Create a long option that is optional and does not take an argument.

attributes.value: / Create a long option that is optional and does not take an argument.
/ * `short_name` - e.g. `"h"` for a `-h` option, or `""` for none
/ * `long_name` - e.g. `"help"` for a `--help` option, or `""` for none
/ * `desc` - Description for usage help

defs.name: optflagmulti
defs.docs:
Create a long option that can occur more than once and does not
 take an argument.

attributes.value: / Create a long option that can occur more than once and does not
/ take an argument.
/ * `short_name` - e.g. `"h"` for a `-h` option, or `""` for none
/ * `long_name` - e.g. `"help"` for a `--help` option, or `""` for none
/ * `desc` - Description for usage help

defs.name: optflagopt
defs.docs: Create a long option that is optional and takes an optional argument.

attributes.value: / Create a long option that is optional and takes an optional argument.
/ * `short_name` - e.g. `"h"` for a `-h` option, or `""` for none
/ * `long_name` - e.g. `"help"` for a `--help` option, or `""` for none
/ * `desc` - Description for usage help
/ * `hint` - Hint that is used in place of the argument in the usage help,
/   e.g. `"FILE"` for a `-o FILE` option

defs.name: optmulti
defs.docs:
Create a long option that is optional, takes an argument, and may occur
 multiple times.

attributes.value: / Create a long option that is optional, takes an argument, and may occur
/ multiple times.
/ * `short_name` - e.g. `"h"` for a `-h` option, or `""` for none
/ * `long_name` - e.g. `"help"` for a `--help` option, or `""` for none
/ * `desc` - Description for usage help
/ * `hint` - Hint that is used in place of the argument in the usage help,
/   e.g. `"FILE"` for a `-o FILE` option

defs.name: parse
defs.value: pub fn parse<C: IntoIterator>(&Self, C) -> Result where C::Item: AsRef<OsStr>
defs.docs: Parse command line arguments according to the provided options.

attributes.value: / Parse command line arguments according to the provided options.
/ On success returns `Ok(Matches)`. Use methods such as `opt_present`
/ `opt_str`, etc. to interrogate results.
/ # Panics
/ Returns `Err(Fail)` on failure: use the `Debug` implementation of `Fail`
/ to display information about it.

defs.docs: Derive a short one-line usage summary from a set of long options.

attributes.value: / Derive a short one-line usage summary from a set of long options.

defs.name: FloatingFrees
defs.docs: Flags and "free" arguments can be freely inter-mixed.

attributes.value: / Flags and "free" arguments can be freely inter-mixed.

defs.name: StopAtFirstFree
defs.docs:
As soon as a "free" argument (i.e. non-flag) is encountered, stop
 considering any remaining arguments as flags.

attributes.value: / As soon as a "free" argument (i.e. non-flag) is encountered, stop
/ considering any remaining arguments as flags.

defs.docs: Describes whether an option has an argument.

defs.docs: Describes how often an option may occur.

The result of checking command line arguments. Contains a vector
 of matches and a vector of free strings.

defs.name: ArgumentMissing
defs.docs: The option requires an argument but none was passed.

attributes.value: / The option requires an argument but none was passed.

defs.name: UnrecognizedOption
defs.docs: The passed option is not declared among the possible options.

attributes.value: / The passed option is not declared among the possible options.

defs.name: OptionMissing
defs.docs: A required option is not present.

attributes.value: / A required option is not present.

defs.name: OptionDuplicated
defs.docs: A single occurrence option is being used multiple times.

attributes.value: / A single occurrence option is being used multiple times.

defs.name: UnexpectedArgument
defs.docs: There's an argument being passed to a non-argument option.

attributes.value: / There's an argument being passed to a non-argument option.

defs.name: Fail
defs.value:
pub enum Fail {
    ArgumentMissing(String),
    UnrecognizedOption(String),
    OptionMissing(String),
    OptionDuplicated(String),
    UnexpectedArgument(String),
}
defs.docs:

 expected format. Use the `Debug` implementation to output detailed
 information.

Returns a vector of the arguments provided to all matches of the given
 option.

Returns a vector of the arguments provided to all matches of the given

defs.name: opt_str
defs.docs: Returns the string argument supplied to a matching option or `None`.

attributes.value: / Returns the string argument supplied to a matching option or `None`.

defs.name: opt_default
defs.docs: Returns the matching string, a default, or `None`.

attributes.value: / Returns the matching string, a default, or `None`.
/ Returns `None` if the option was not present, `def` if the option was
/ present but no argument was provided, and the argument if the option was
/ present and an argument was provided.

defs.name: opt_get
defs.value:
pub fn opt_get<T>(&Self, &str) -> result::Result<Option<T>, T::Err> where
T: FromStr
defs.docs: Returns some matching value or `None`.

attributes.value: / Returns some matching value or `None`.
/ Similar to opt_str, also converts matching argument using FromStr.

defs.name: opt_get_default
defs.value:
pub fn opt_get_default<T>(&Self, &str, T) -> result::Result<T, T::Err> where
T: FromStr
defs.docs: Returns a matching value or default.

attributes.value: / Returns a matching value or default.
/ Similar to opt_default, except the two differences.
/ Instead of returning None when argument was not present, return `def`.
/ Instead of returning &str return type T, parsed using str::parse().
